item.title:
RT by @fede_intern: Just catching up on this and wanted to chime in with a few thoughts:
From my perspective, saying that a rollup is only truly “based” if it operates without trusted gateways is like “throwing out the baby with the bath water”. There is a broad spectrum between centralised sequencing running purely on trust (fully trusted, single-operator sequencer) and free-for-all / total-anarchy (fully permissionless) based sequencing.
Within that spectrum, there is room for some trust assumptions and permissioning to simplify liveness, performance, and MEV guarantees, while keeping these parties accountable via more robust, trustless mechanisms (for example, staked gateways subject to slashing). There are nuances around fault attribution for liveness failures, but in general robust mechanisms can ensure gateways abide by their promises (such as not reneging on a preconfirmation).
A world in which multiple semi-trusted, permissioned gateways sequence a rollup on behalf of L1 proposers (via delegation) is, in my view, strictly better than a single centralised sequencer. Not only does it improve robustness, it also fosters innovation and higher performance by incentivising better service. Involving L1 proposers is crucial for composability with the L1, and giving them oversight over delegated gateways creates a competitive market that encourages gateways to provide superior services.
Regarding MEV, the gateway still acts as an auctioneer, but in accordance with the MEV policies set by rollup operators, so I see no reason why it would undermine MEV-democratisation.
Again, this is just one point on the spectrum between fully centralised and trusted, and fully permissionless based sequencing. Rollup operators can decide how "based" they wish to be by weighing the various trade-offs and choosing what works best for their ecosystem, level of trust, permissioned or not etc. In practice, there will most likely never be a one-size-fits-all solution.
The goal should be to shift more and more towards fully permissionless, ‘based’ sequencing, and to improve on the status quo at each step along the way.
Finally, regarding complexity: any approach to decentralised sequencing, whether “based”, shared, BFT, and so on, will inevitably introduce additional complexities. There are always trade-offs to be made.
cc @jessepollak @mteamisloading
